items.title: Upstream release of dependency: cfitsio 3.49
items.body:
This is a message from an automated system that monitors `cfitsio` releases (also see spacetelescope/hstcal#519).

**Version 3.49 - Aug 2020**

  - Fix to imcompress.c.  It now turns off quantization if ZSCALE and ZZERO columns are missing.  Treatment will be the same as     if ZQUANTIZ were set to 'NONE', even if ZQUANTIZ is present and set to something else.

  - Added mutex to fits_execute_template() function so that the creation of files using ASCII templates will be thread safe.
    		   
  - In fpack when using -table flag, replaced warning message with a more detailed description mentioning FITS format update.
		   
  - Added flag to CMake builds to disable curl dependency.  Also only add CURL_LIBRARIES to CMake link target if curl is found.
		   
  - Minor adjustment to download progress output.

cc @saimn @embray

items.body:

items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,

by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

Example log: https://travis-ci.org/github/astropy/astropy/jobs/717518434 (first 2 failures)

```
____________________________ test_regression_10092 _____________________________
    def test_regression_10092():
        """
        Check that we still get a proper motion even for SkyCoords without distance
        """
        c = SkyCoord(l=10*u.degree, b=45*u.degree,
                     pm_l_cosb=34*u.mas/u.yr, pm_b=-117*u.mas/u.yr,
                     frame='galactic',
                     obstime=Time('1988-12-18 05:11:23.5'))
    
        with pytest.warns(ErfaWarning, match='ERFA function "pmsafe" yielded .*'):
            # expect ErfaWarning here
>           newc = c.apply_space_motion(dt=10*u.year)
E           Failed: DID NOT WARN. No warnings of type (<class 'erfa.core.ErfaWarning'>,) matching ('ERFA function "pmsafe" yielded .*') was emitted. The list of emitted warnings is: [ErfaWarning('ERFA function \'pmsafe\' yielded 1 of "distance overridden (Note 6)"')].
../../.tox/py37-test-devdeps/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/coordinates/tests/test_regression.py:641: Failed
___________________________ test_apply_space_motion ____________________________
    def test_apply_space_motion():
        # use this 12 year period because it's a multiple of 4 to avoid the quirks
        # of leap years while having 2 leap seconds in it
        t1 = Time('2000-01-01T00:00')
        t2 = Time('2012-01-01T00:00')
    
        # Check a very simple case first:
        frame = ICRS(ra=10.*u.deg, dec=0*u.deg,
                     distance=10.*u.pc,
                     pm_ra_cosdec=0.1*u.deg/u.yr,
                     pm_dec=0*u.mas/u.yr,
                     radial_velocity=0*u.km/u.s)
    
        # Cases that should work (just testing input for now):
        c1 = SkyCoord(frame, obstime=t1, pressure=101*u.kPa)
        with pytest.warns(ErfaWarning, match='ERFA function "pmsafe" yielded .*'):
            # warning raised due to high PM chosen above
            applied1 = c1.apply_space_motion(new_obstime=t2)
>           applied2 = c1.apply_space_motion(dt=12*u.year)
E           Failed: DID NOT WARN. No warnings of type (<class 'erfa.core.ErfaWarning'>,) matching ('ERFA function "pmsafe" yielded .*') was emitted. The list of emitted warnings is: [ErfaWarning('ERFA function \'pmsafe\' yielded 1 of "distance overridden (Note 6)"'), ErfaWarning('ERFA function \'pmsafe\' yielded 1 of "distance overridden (Note 6)"')].
../../.tox/py37-test-devdeps/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/coordinates/tests/test_sky_coord.py:1613: Failed
```

If the warning is no longer emitted on purpose, `pytest.warns` needs to be removed. Otherwise, if a warning is expected, this is a symptom of a bug.

items.title: Unable to download Github Pages URL
items.body:
### Description

Discovered `[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED]` error on macOS. I've created a fresh environment to run tests

#### URL
```
https://datum-storage.org/exovetter/mapQ1Q17DR24-DVMed6084.mat
```

#### Machine Info
```
Software:

    System Software Overview:

      System Version: macOS 10.13.6 (17G13035)
      Kernel Version: Darwin 17.7.0
      Boot Volume: Macintosh HD
      Boot Mode: Normal
      Computer Name: <redacted>
      User Name: <redacted>
      Secure Virtual Memory: Enabled
      System Integrity Protection: Enabled
      Time since boot: 5 days 18:59
```

#### Cert Chain Info
```
$ openssl s_client -connect datum-storage.org
Certificate chain
 0 s:CN = datum-storage.org
   i:C = US, O = Let's Encrypt, CN = Let's Encrypt Authority X3
 1 s:C = US, O = Let's Encrypt, CN = Let's Encrypt Authority X3
   i:O = Digital Signature Trust Co., CN = DST Root CA X3
```

#### Stack Track ( Python )
```
self = <urllib.request.HTTPSHandler object at 0x109c21e48>, http_class = <class 'http.client.HTTPSConnection'>, req = <urllib.request.Request object at 0x10997d668>, http_conn_args = {'check_hostname': None, 'context': None}, host = 'datum-storage.org', h = <http.client.HTTPSConnection object at 0x109c21f98>

    def do_open(self, http_class, req, **http_conn_args):
        """Return an HTTPResponse object for the request, using http_class.
    
        http_class must implement the HTTPConnection API from http.client.
        """
        host = req.host
        if not host:
            raise URLError('no host given')
    
        # will parse host:port
        h = http_class(host, timeout=req.timeout, **http_conn_args)
        h.set_debuglevel(self._debuglevel)
    
        headers = dict(req.unredirected_hdrs)
        headers.update({k: v for k, v in req.headers.items()
                        if k not in headers})
    
        # TODO(jhylton): Should this be redesigned to handle
        # persistent connections?
    
        # We want to make an HTTP/1.1 request, but the addinfourl
        # class isn't prepared to deal with a persistent connection.
        # It will try to read all remaining data from the socket,
        # which will block while the server waits for the next request.
        # So make sure the connection gets closed after the (only)
        # request.
        headers["Connection"] = "close"
        headers = {name.title(): val for name, val in headers.items()}
    
        if req._tunnel_host:
            tunnel_headers = {}
            proxy_auth_hdr = "Proxy-Authorization"
            if proxy_auth_hdr in headers:
                tunnel_headers[proxy_auth_hdr] = headers[proxy_auth_hdr]
                # Proxy-Authorization should not be sent to origin
                # server.
                del headers[proxy_auth_hdr]
            h.set_tunnel(req._tunnel_host, headers=tunnel_headers)
    
        try:
            try:
                h.request(req.get_method(), req.selector, req.data, headers,
                          encode_chunked=req.has_header('Transfer-encoding'))
            except OSError as err: # timeout error
>               raise URLError(err)
E               urllib.error.URLError: <urlopen error [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: unable to get local issuer certificate (_ssl.c:1056)>

/sw/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py:1319: URLError
========================================================================================================================================================================= 1 failed in 0.42 seconds =========================================================================================================================================================================
```

#### Expected behavior
The domain `datum-storage.org` points to https://github.com/jbcurtin/datum-storage.org and is a Github Pages site. Github Pages implements Let's Encrypt SSL signed by DST Root CA X3 which can be found in the approved certs-list for macOS Sierra. https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208127

Downloading a URL from a server that uses Let's Encrypt _should work_. It works as expected in Python's `psf/requests`.

#### Steps to Reproduce
Here is a code example to reproduce the error using `pytest`

Create the necessary files
```
$ mkdir -p /tmp/steps-to-reproduce/tests
$ cd /tmp/steps-to-reproduce
$ conda create -n steps-to-reproduce python=3.7 pytest astropy
$ conda activate steps-to-reproduce
```

Create `tests/test_download_file.py`
```
from astropy.utils import data

MAT_FILE_URL = 'https://datum-storage.org/exovetter/mapQ1Q17DR24-DVMed6084.mat'

def test__download_file() -> None:
  mat_file_data = data.download_file(MAT_FILE_URL)
```
Run `pytest`
```
$ pytest tests
```

If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

@aarchiba , `clear_download_cache` appears to be sensitive to trailing slash. Is it a bug or feature? Will fixing this introduce other bugs for other variation of inputs?

This is a follow up issue of #10437.

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->

If I tell it to clear `https://domain` whereas I cached the URL as `https://domain/`, there should be no difference.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->

Cached `https://domain/` isn't cleared.

### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

```python
>>> from astropy.utils.data import import_file_to_cache, get_cached_urls, clear_download_cache
>>> import_file_to_cache('https://example.com/', 'README.md')
'/path/to/.astropy/cache/download/url/182ccedb33a9e03fbf1079b209da1a31/contents'
>>> get_cached_urls()
['https://example.com/']
>>> clear_download_cache('https://example.com')  # No trailing slash
>>> get_cached_urls()
['https://example.com/']
>>> clear_download_cache('https://example.com/')
>>> get_cached_urls()                                                                          
[]
```

items.title: wcs fails on CTYPE1  = 'GLON---TAN'
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
WCS dies with InconsistentAxisTypeError on CTYPE1  = 'GLON---TAN' 

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
astropy.wcs should parse this WSC properly to overlay coordinate grids in plots etc.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->
```
WARNING: FITSFixedWarning: 'celfix' made the change 'Unrecognized projection code (--T in CTYPE1)'. [astropy.wcs.wcs]

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
InconsistentAxisTypesError                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-51ecd8e47fa1> in <module>
----> 1 wcs = WCS(hdu.header)

~\.julia\conda\3\lib\site-packages\astropy\wcs\wcs.py in __init__(self, header, fobj, key, minerr, relax, naxis, keysel, colsel, fix, translate_units, _do_set)
    510 
    511         if _do_set:
--> 512             self.wcs.set()
    513 
    514         for fd in close_fds:

InconsistentAxisTypesError: ERROR 4 in wcs_types() at line 2747 of file cextern\wcslib\C\wcs.c:
Unrecognized projection code (--T in CTYPE1).
```

<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

```python

from astropy.io import fits
# this straight from MAST https://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/hpsgc/
f = 'hlsp_hpsgc_hst_nicmos-nic3_gc_palpha_v1_img.fits'
hdu = fits.open(f)[0]
hdu.header

# produces

items.title: TST: Table doctest failures with pandas 1.1.0
items.body:
`pandas` 1.1.0 was released about 6 hours ago. Now we see this failure "Python 3.8 with all optional dependencies" job in Travis CI initial stage.

items.title: Inconsistent and "lossy" return values from `SigmaClip`
items.body:
### Description
In June 2018, `SigmaClip.__call__` was split into `_sigmaclip_noaxis` and `_sigmaclip_withaxis` branches. The former branch optimizes the simplest cases by removing deviant pixels during processing, whilst the latter [now tracks deviant values by substituting `NaN`s in the data array instead of using a `MaskedArray`](https://github.com/astropy/astropy/commit/96f20287634c40faef7a43e4ee90140010e05652). This has led to a couple of probably-unintended changes in API when using the `axis` parameter:

* With `masked=True` (the default & previous behaviour), the `MaskedArray` that gets returned now has `NaN` values in its main data array. These special values are unnecessary because the corresponding elements are already masked. Moreover, changing them to `NaN` discards useful information about what the masked values were. This is undesirable eg. when plotting the data with deviant values annotated.

* When providing an integer array as input, it gets upcast to `float64`, which also seems unexpected and shouldn't happen implicitly if avoidable.

These are **inconsistent with the behaviour for `axis=None` and for `copy=False`** -- options which shouldn't affect what the return value looks like.

Specifying `masked=False` also produces `NaN`s -- but in that case the behaviour is a documented new form of usage, where `NaN` values are used in place of a mask (and thus the return type has to be some kind of float).

<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

### Expected behavior
I expect to get back a `MaskedArray` that's the same as the input `data` but with a mask attached. I don't expect the output `dtype` or the presence of `NaN` values to depend on the `axis` or `copy` parameters.

### Actual behavior
With `masked=True` and `axis=0`, the `MaskedArray` returned has `NaN` at masked pixels and is upcast to `float64`.

### Steps to Reproduce

Note that `axis=None` and `axis=0` mean exactly the same thing here (clip over the only axis), but they trigger different branches in the code.
```python
import numpy as np
from astropy.stats import sigma_clip

data_in = np.array([-2, 5, -5, -6, 20, 14, 1])

print('In               ', data_in)

data_out = sigma_clip(data_in, sigma=1.5, maxiters=3)

print('\nNoaxis_data      ', data_out.data)
print('Noaxis_mask      ', data_out.mask)

data_out = sigma_clip(data_in, sigma=1.5, maxiters=3, axis=0)

print('\nWithaxis_data    ', data_out.data)
print('Withaxis_mask    ', data_out.mask)

data_out = sigma_clip(data_in, sigma=1.5, maxiters=3, axis=0, copy=False)

print('\nWithaxis_no_copy ', data_out.data)

data_out = sigma_clip(data_in, sigma=1.5, maxiters=3, axis=0, masked=False)

print('\nWithaxis_no_mask ', data_out)
```
```
In                [-2  5 -5 -6 20 14  1]

Noaxis_data       [-2  5 -5 -6 20 14  1]
Noaxis_mask       [False  True False False  True  True False]

Withaxis_data     [-2. nan -5. -6. nan nan  1.]
Withaxis_mask     [False  True False False  True  True False]

Withaxis_no_copy  [-2  5 -5 -6 20 14  1]

Withaxis_no_mask  [-2. nan -5. -6. nan nan  1.]
```

### System Details
Linux-3.10.0-1127.13.1.el7.x86_64-x86_64-with-centos-7.8.2003-Core
Python 3.6.9 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Jul 30 2019, 19:07:31) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
Numpy 1.17.2
astropy 4.1.dev1967+g02fb00a
Scipy 1.3.1
Matplotlib 3.1.1

### Solution

This can be fixed in 1 line by adding `filtered_data = np.ma.MaskedArray(data, filtered_data.mask, copy=True)` after [L381](https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/055c0ad984869538a0d6fa97391ff5486ec922fd/astropy/stats/sigma_clipping.py#L381) of `_sigmaclip_withaxis`. I'm already working on a PR for this same class and can just include the fix there, following any discussion here. Thanks.

items.title: HDUList does not close file if filename is pathlib.Path
items.body:
If I write a FITS file and provide the filename as a `pathlib.Path` object, the file is not closed

### How to reproduce

```python
from astropy.io import fits
import pathlib
hdulist = fits.HDUList([fits.PrimaryHDU()])
print("Use pathlib.Path")
hdulist.writeto(pathlib.Path("e.fits"), overwrite=True)
print("Use string")
hdulist.writeto("e.fits", overwrite=True)
```

Running this:

```
python -Wd writeto_path.py
Use pathlib.Path
/home/zonca/zonca/p/software/healpy/healpyvenv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/utils/decorators.py:535: ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.FileIO name='e.fits' mode='wb' closefd=True>
  return function(*args, **kwargs)
Use string
```

### Possible issue

I think the issue is at https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/a6a350570aec6600eb907fe9903585dd18dc0874/astropy/io/fits/hdu/hdulist.py#L927
It checks if the input file is `str`, it would be nice to check also for `pathlib.Path`.

items.title: Time creation for unix time is very slow
items.body:
This issue is very likely related to #5846 and #10167.

When using `astropy.time.Time` to convert unix timestamps (or utime) to datetime, it's more than factor 1000 slower than using `datetime.utcfromtimestamp()`.

I benchmarked converting 2000 values, which is not even much when reading fits files
```python
Time(times[i], format="unix")  # 1.61s
datetime.utcfromtimestamp(times[i])  # 998µs

Time(times[i], format="utime")  # 1.74s
datetime.utcfromtimestamp(times[i] + offset)  # 2ms, offset being set to Time(0, format="utime").to_value("unix")
```

Astropy does some special checks for leap seconds and so on, but I haven't found an example where the native conversion differs from astropy using seconds as the smallest unit.. is there any at all? If not, would it be feasible to convert those two formats using the native `datetime` module? If not, what is causing this huge difference..? seems a bit strange to me

items.title: BUG: `constants.pc` definition does not use small angle approximation
items.body:
### Description
As reported on the [mailing list](https://mail.python.org/pipermail/astropy/2020-July/004772.html) the definition of the parsec in https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/28349153fcc25a9ca01bb5e563c86177c50aed1d/astropy/constants/iau2015.py#L29
uses the exact distance for a 1"-parallax object `c.au / np.tan(u.arcsec.to('radian'))` rather than the small-angle approximation `c.au / u.arcsec.to('radian')`. However the [IAU 2015 resolution B2](https://www.iau.org/static/resolutions/IAU2015_English.pdf) states (footnote 4) that 
> The parsec is defined as exactly (648 000/π) au (e.g. Cox 2000, Binney & Tremaine 2008).

([small-angle approximation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec#cite_note-11)).
### Expected behavior
```
from astropy import constants as apc
from astropy import units as apu
print(apc.au.value * 180 * 3600 / np.pi)
3.085677581491367e+16 
```
### Actual behavior
```
print(apc.pc.value)
print(apc.au.value / np.tan(np.pi / (180 * 3600)))
3.0856775814671916e+16
3.0856775814671916e+16
```

Fixing the value in `iau2015.py` is trivial; perhaps to be discussed if the change should also be copied into `iau2012.py` (which implicitly certainly assumed the same definition, but did not state this).
Also `equivalencies=u.parallax()` will probably need to be adapted as well.

items.title: Lossless gzip compression of floating-point fits image data puts incorrect ZQUANTIZ header value
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
Writing floating point image data with lossless gzip compression (specifying `quantize_level=0.0`) sets `ZQUANTIZ='NO_DITHER'` in the compressed HDU header.  This is incompatible with cfitsio and funpack, which expects `ZQUANTIZ='NONE'` for unquantized data.  If you run `funpack` on a file compressed in this way you get garbage data (but no error is raised).  Note that this bug is only triggered when you explicitly set `quantize_level=0.0`, and is not triggered when quantization is automatically turned off when the fits writer cannot compute a good RMS.

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
What I expect is that compressed data written by `astropy.io.fits` is readable by other standard fits readers.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->
What actually happens is that you get garbage data when running `funpack` on an image compressed in this way.

### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

The following code assumes that `funpack` is available in the system path.

```python
import astropy.io.fits as fits
import numpy as np
import subprocess
import os
import mmap


arr = np.random.normal(size=(1000, 1000), loc=100.0, scale=10.0)

hdu_list = fits.HDUList()
hdu = fits.CompImageHDU(data=arr, header=fits.Header(),
                        compression_type='GZIP_2', quantize_level=0)
hdu_list.append(hdu)
hdu_list.writeto('test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz', overwrite=True)

arr2 = fits.getdata('test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz', ext=0)

# This test succeeds because astropy.io.fits can read these files
np.testing.assert_array_almost_equal(arr2, arr)

# Use funpack to uncompress test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz
if os.path.isfile("test_gzip_compressed_image.fits"):
    os.unlink("test_gzip_compressed_image.fits")
subprocess.run(["funpack", "test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz"])

arr3 = fits.getdata('test_gzip_compressed_image.fits', ext=0)

# This will fail because the funpack uncompress failed (silently)
np.testing.assert_array_almost_equal(arr3, arr)

# Replace the ZQUANTIZ= 'NO_DITHER' header value with NONE
# Do this manually because the Z* header keywords are reserved
with open('test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz', "r+b") as f:
    mm = mmap.mmap(f.fileno(), 0)
    loc = mm.find(b"ZQUANTIZ= 'NO_DITHER'")
    if loc >= 0:
        mm.seek(loc)
        mm.write(b"ZQUANTIZ= 'NONE     '")

# Use funpack to uncompress the updated version
if os.path.isfile("test_gzip_compressed_image.fits"):
    os.unlink("test_gzip_compressed_image.fits")
subprocess.run(["funpack", "test_gzip_compressed_image.fits.fz"])

arr3 = fits.getdata('test_gzip_compressed_image.fits', ext=0)

# The following test works, the arrays are equal.
np.testing.assert_array_almost_equal(arr3, arr)
```

items.title: Error generated while installing the astropy using pip command
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .

by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

Using the $ pip install astropy in my windows running machine, below error was generated. Appreciate very much for the given the solution for the issue

Run and Install the astropy.

items.title: Performance of Table creation from Python lists
items.body:
This is mostly a question to understand what is causing the following performance hit in initialization of a table from Python lists:

```python
In [238]: import numpy as np
     ...: from astropy import table
     ...: time = list(np.random.randint(0, 1000000, 100000))
     ...: rate = list(np.random.randint(0, 1000000, 100000))
     ...: error = list(np.random.randint(0, 1000000, 100000))

In [239]: %timeit table.Table([time, rate, error], names=["time", "rate", "error"])
673 ms ± 14.5 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)

In [240]: %timeit data = table.Table([np.array(time), np.array(rate), np.array(error)], \
     ...:                             names=["time", "rate", "error"])
17 ms ± 224 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100 loops each)
```
That was with:
```
astropy: 4.2.dev360
numpy: 1.18.0
```
With updated `numpy` to `1.19.0`, timing difference is even larger:
```
In [2]: %timeit table.Table([time, rate, error], names=["time", "rate", "error"])
861 ms ± 7.78 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)

In [3]: %timeit table.Table([np.array(time), np.array(rate), np.array(error)], \
   ...:                     names=["time", "rate", "error"])
16.5 ms ± 401 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100 loops each)
```

EDIT: Benchmark added in astropy/astropy-benchmarks#97

items.title: TST: Test against system libraries (cfitsio, wcslib, erfa, expat)
items.body:
To avoid a repeat of issues like #10534 , where things are broken when package is built against system libraries over the bundled ones.

cc @astrofrog @saimn @nden

items.title: 4.1rc1: Numpy headers not found when using system cfitsio or wcslib
items.body:
I am trying to prepare the openSUSE package for the next release, [working with 4.1rc1](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:bnavigator:branches:devel:languages:python:numeric/python-astropy-rc).

I am running into compilation errors when trying to unbundle cfitsio and wcslib. Some subpackages do not find the numpy headers. The proper include parameter for gcc is missing:

With `ASTROPY_USE_SYSTEM_CFITSIO=1`:
```
...
[   35s] building 'astropy.io.ascii.cparser' extension
[   35s] creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io
[   35s] creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io/ascii
[   35s] creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io/ascii/src
[   35s] gcc -pthread -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -DOPENSSL_LOAD_CONF -fwrapv -fno-semantic-interposition -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -fPIC -I/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/numpy/core/include -I/usr/include/python3.8 -c astropy/io/ascii/cparser.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io/ascii/cparser.o
...
[   46s] building 'astropy.io.fits.compression' extension
[   46s] creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io/fits
[   46s] creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/astropy/io/fits/src
[   46s] gcc -pthread -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -DOPENSSL_LOAD_CONF -fwrapv -fno-semantic-interposition -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector-strong -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -Werror=return-type -g -fPIC -U_REENTRANT -I/usr/include/cfitsio -I/usr/include/python3.8 -c ./astropy/io/fits/src/compressionmodule.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/./astropy/io/fits/src/compressionmodule.o

Note that  `astropy.io.ascii.cparser`  has the `-I...numpy..` parameter,  `astropy.io.fits.compression` does not.

With `ASTROPY_USE_SYSTEM_WCSLIB=1`:
```

items.title: MNT: Undo numpydoc pin when we can
items.body:
This is a follow-up of #10524 . When a new version of something (numpydoc, Sphinx, automodapi, etc) comes out upstream that fixes the `:py:class reference target not found:` warnings, we should remove this pinning:

https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/3a8732fd2e99653fca8e766fc72245ca98b240cd/setup.cfg#L76

If even then, some fix to our own docstrings is still needed, that fix should be applied as well.

items.title: fitscheck should not be using astropy.tests.helper.catch_warnings
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

`fitscheck` uses `astropy.tests.helper.catch_warnings`:

https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/49708febbdaa1d1bf53f96981bf1f1d71295d33d/astropy/io/fits/scripts/fitscheck.py#L134

It should not be using a function from "test helper" module because that makes `pytest` a compulsory dependency whenever this import happens:

https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/49708febbdaa1d1bf53f96981bf1f1d71295d33d/astropy/io/fits/scripts/fitscheck.py#L47

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->

Any non-test function should not be using stuff in `astropy.tests`.

### Blocker

An attempt to replace it with `warnings.catch_warnings` failed in #10504 , which @saimn explained beautifully at https://github.com/astropy/sphinx-astropy/issues/21#issuecomment-653692416 : 

*Basically Astropy's `catch_warnings` is overwriting the warnings defined in `setup.cfg` for pytest, by calling `treat_deprecations_as_exceptions` in its `__exit__` method. So the global `error` clause in pytest's config was ignored once Astropy's `catch_warnings` was called... When using `warnings.catch_warnings` this does not happen, so the global `error` clause is there, and the checksum verification in `io.fits` is issuing warning when the checksum is wrong, which turns into errors, which break the code's logic...*

items.title: Should TableColumns keys and values be generators now?
items.body:
I stumbled upon this:

https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/1f75aa164539949723971d5b767f9517a3d77344/astropy/table/table.py#L285-L290

The comment said they were defined for PY2/PY3 compatibility. We have dropped PY2 since v3.0. Ideally, we should also be able to remove these if they were indeed only for compatibility. However, they revert to PY2 behavior, which makes removal impossible in the PY3 world. Should `keys` and `values` really by generators now?

items.title: Add copy=False option to Quantity.to
items.body:
### Description
Currently `Quantity.to` always makes a copy of the data, even if the target unit is the same. It would be useful to call `q.to(u.m, copy=False)` which would only copy if necessary.

### Additional context
While the newish `<<` operator helps to reduce copies, it can lead to mistakes because it does two unrelated things:
1. If the left side is a quantity, it performance unit conversion (like `Quantity.to`, but only copying if necessary);
2. If the left side is some other array-like, it performs Quantity construction (like `*`, but only copying if necessary).

If a function is supposed to take a Quantity and uses `<<` to ensure that it is working in a particular unit (maybe so that future arithmetic operations won't need to do conversions, or so that unit errors are caught early), the user could accidentally pass a plain ndarray (which could be in any units) and instead of failing, it will be assumed that it's in whatever units are being converted to.

Additionally, `<<` is not convenient for working with equivalencies.

items.title: TimeDelta does not support np.sum anymore
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,

If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
In the development version of Astropy the `TimeDelta` object does not work with `np.sum()` anymore. The issue was found in one of our [Gammapy Travis-CI builds](https://travis-ci.org/github/gammapy/gammapy/jobs/699226524#L8080). I presume the issue is somehow related to https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/8610, but I could not find a statement whether it is intended behaviour.



### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
I would expect that the expression `np.sum(time_delta)` just returns the sum of the time differences

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->
The code fails with a `TypeError`:

```
TypeError: no implementation found for 'numpy.sum' on types that implement __array_function__: [<class 'astropy.time.core.TimeDelta'>]
```


### Steps to Reproduce
The following code example reproduces the error:

```python
from astropy.time import Time
import numpy as np

t_1 = Time(['1999-01-01T00:00:00.123456789', '2010-01-01T00:00:00'])
t_2 = Time(['1998-01-01T00:00:00.123456789', '2009-01-01T00:00:00'])
total = np.sum(t_1 - t_2)
```

items.title: Meaning of empty string keywords in fits.Header
items.body:
This is mostly a question at this moment (and possibly a bug report) as I simply do not understand the meaning of empty string keywords in `fits.Header`. Here is an example of what I am talking about:

```python
In [38]: from astropy.io import fits
    ...: hdr = fits.Header()
    ...: hdr[''] = 1
    ...: hdr[''] = 2
    ...: hdr[''] = 3
    ...: print(repr(hdr))
        1
        2
        3

In [39]: hdr[' ']
Out[39]: 1

In [40]: hdr['  ']
Out[40]: 1

In [41]: hdr['']
Out[41]: ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
~/.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py in __call__(self, obj)
    700                 type_pprinters=self.type_printers,
    701                 deferred_pprinters=self.deferred_printers)
--> 702             printer.pretty(obj)
    703             printer.flush()
    704             return stream.getvalue()

~/.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/lib/pretty.py in pretty(self, obj)
    392                         if cls is not object \
    393                                 and callable(cls.__dict__.get('__repr__')):
--> 394                             return _repr_pprint(obj, self, cycle)
    395
    396             return _default_pprint(obj, self, cycle)

~/.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/lib/pretty.py in _repr_pprint(obj, p, cycle)
    682     """A pprint that just redirects to the normal repr function."""
    683     # Find newlines and replace them with p.break_()
--> 684     output = repr(obj)
    685     lines = output.splitlines()
    686     with p.group():

~/.../astropy/astropy/io/fits/header.py in __repr__(self)
   2230
   2231     def __repr__(self):
-> 2232         return '\n'.join(self)
   2233
   2234     def __getitem__(self, idx):

TypeError: sequence item 0: expected str instance, int found
```

First of all it is strange that empty strings (`''`) are allowed as keywords, and then that `Header` stores each value without replacing it, and then that it actually works to get the value using strings with at least one space character (`hdr[' ']`) but it crashes if I actually try to use an empty string as a key (`hdr['']`).

If this is a bug, I am not sure what to report as a bug:
1. allowing setting empty string header keywords (`hdr[''] = 1`);
2. not overwriting existing values;
3. crashing when trying to retrieve `hdr['']`.

items.title: Inconsistent representation of empty string values in repr(fits.Header)
items.body:
`repr(fits.Header)` prints different representations for empty or space only string values even though it seems like the values are reported as empty strings.

Here is an example:
```python

    ...: hdr = fits.Header(
    ...:     [
    ...:         ('KEY1', 1),
    ...:         ('KEY2', 2),
    ...:         ('KEY3', 3),
    ...:         ('REFSTR', '123'),
    ...:         ('WSTR0', ''),
    ...:         ('WSTR1', ' '),
    ...:         ('WSTR2', '  '),
    ...:         ('WSTR0-2', '')
    ...:     ]
    ...: )

    ...: print(len(hdr['REFSTR']))
    ...: print(len(hdr['WSTR0']))
    ...: print(len(hdr['WSTR1']))
    ...: print(len(hdr['WSTR2']))
    ...: print(len(hdr['WSTR0-2']))

command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

When astropy is run on a cluster, many processes operate at once, often nearly simultaneously. If data from the Net is required, all processes are liable to request it nearly simultaneously, which is likely to cause problems. This can usually be detected when a torrent of error and failure messages appear, and prevented by loading the appropriate files into the astropy cache from a single process, up front. A key exception is when the IERS data becomes too old and needs to be refreshed; this is not easy for users to anticipate and can cause surprising problems with a job that ran fine yesterday.

Specifically:

- Request IERS data from astropy in a single process.
- Submit a cluster job that requires that same IERS data from many machines.
- Set the `auto_max_age` configuration variable to `0`.
- Re-submit the same cluster job that requires that same IERS data from many machines.

Probably only detectable after solving #9970 

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->

Re-submitted jobs succeed, or fail in some way that the user can understand and that either loads the cache or tells the user how to do this.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->

Many downloads are attempted at once, hammering the server and causing at least some of them to fail, producing exceptions in many jobs describing problems accessing a particular server.

Also triggers concurrency problems even with #10437 - though an extension to that might be able to resolve this issue.

### System Details

Please run the following snippet and paste the output below:

import astropy; print("astropy", astropy.__version__)
import scipy; print("Scipy", scipy.__version__)
import matplotlib; print("Matplotlib", matplotlib.__version__)
-->

items.title: Keywords' values are not replaced in fits.Header when keywords end in space
items.body:
### Description
Normally, when a keyword in `astropy.io.fits.Header` is set twice second value replaces previous value of the same keyword. This does not happen when keywords end in space (`' '`)

### Expected behavior
I would expect that setting a keyword value of a keyword like `'KEY '` to 1 (first time) and to 2 (second time), the second value would replace the first value.

### Actual behavior
When setting a keyword value of a keyword like `'KEY '` to 1 (first time) and to 2 (second time), the second value **does not** replace the first value. Instead the header has two cards with the same keyword with two different values (1 and 2 in this case).

### Steps to Reproduce

```python
In [1]: from astropy.io import fits
   ...: print("--- FIRST iteration ---")
   ...: hdr = fits.Header()
   ...: hdr['KEY1'] = 1
   ...: hdr['KEY2 '] = 2
   ...: print(repr(hdr))
   ...: hdr['KEY1'] = 3
   ...: hdr['KEY2 '] = 4
   ...: print("--- SECOND iteration ---")
   ...: print(repr(hdr))
   ...: print("value of 'KEY2 ' is: {}".format(hdr['KEY2 ']))
--- FIRST iteration ---
KEY1    =                    1
KEY2    =                    2
--- SECOND iteration ---
KEY1    =                    3
KEY2    =                    2
KEY2    =                    4
value of 'KEY2 ' is: 2
```
I would expect the value of `'KEY2 '` to be 4 and that there were just one entry for this keyword in the header.

If space character is supported in keyword names (i.e., if it is simply ignored, like `strip()`), then the behavior should be as expected by me. If space at the end is not supported, then I would expect to see a warning like in the following situation:
```python
In [2]: hdr['a#'] = 9
WARNING: VerifyWarning: Keyword name 'a#' is greater than 8 characters or contains characters not allowed by the FITS standard; a HIERARCH card will be created. [astropy.io.fits.card]

In [3]: hdr['a '] = 9  # No warning!

In [4]:
```

### System Details
```
Darwin-17.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.7.6 (default, Jan  8 2020, 13:42:34)
[Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
Numpy 1.18.0
astropy 4.2.dev167+g8bdd24b04
Scipy 1.3.2
Matplotlib 3.2.0
```

### Description
Running pytest causes doctests to leave lots of test files lying around in the root directory that are not cleaned up. When running pytest a second time, some doctests fail because they do not expect the files to exist.

This issue was supposed to be addressed in the workaround in #9439. But I'm getting it again now with master, and figured it was worth an issue since it's causing tests to fail.

### Expected behavior
Pytest should run without errors no matter how many times you run it.

### Actual behavior
There are 6 doctests that fail if pytest was previously run without cleaning untracked files from the working directory..

items.title: x-axis missing on WCSAxes whole sphere plot
items.body:
### Description
When plotting a full sphere plot (in this case it happens to be a map of the Sun), WCSAxes does not draw the x-axis when the whole map is shown. Example code is given below.

The issue is that the x-axis lies at -180deg, which is technically the same longitude as 180deg. When WCSAxes tries to work out if a given pixel location is within the valid bounds of the transformation
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/64bc74b1cef62ddf9fe764282a18ade3e879028a/astropy/visualization/wcsaxes/wcsapi.py#L356-L358
, it round trips the transformation, ie. for the bottom left corner of the bottom left pixel:
```python
pixel = (-0.5, -0.5)
world = wcs.pixel_to_world_values(*pixel)
pixel2 = wcs.world_to_pixel_values(*world)
```
`pixel2` comes out as `(array(359.5), array(-0.5))` however, which is different to the input pixel, so WCSAxes treats this as invalid, and does not draw x-axis because it thinks the spine has invalid coordinates. I think it is actually on the edge of valid pixel locations, so should be drawn.

Downstream issue at https://github.com/sunpy/sunpy/issues/3611


### Expected behavior
x-axis is drawn.

### Actual behavior
x-axis isn't drawn:
![Figure_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6197628/83689056-4ceec900-a5e6-11ea-92f5-51600df3e6d2.png)


### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from astropy.wcs import WCS

shape = [180, 360]
data = np.random.rand(*shape)
header = {'wcsaxes': 2,
          'crpix1': 180.5,
          'crpix2': 90.5,
          'cdelt1': 1.0,
          'cdelt2': 1.0,
          'cunit1': 'deg',
          'cunit2': 'deg',
          'ctype1': 'CRLN-CAR',
          'ctype2': 'CRLT-CAR',
          'crval1': 0.0,
          'crval2': 0.0,
          'lonpole': 0.0,
          'latpole': 90.0,
          'dateref': '1858-11-17',
          'mjdrefi': 0.0,

items.title: Crash when changing vmin and vmax interactively in matplotlib
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
When interactively changing vmin and vmax of an image shown with imshow, using astropy wcsaxes in the Qt5Agg MPLBACKEND figure editor python exits and an exception is raised. This happens with matplotlib 3.2.1.

### Expected behavior
Successful change of vmin and vmax.

### Actual behavior
Crash of python with backtrace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/matplotlib/backends/qt_editor/_formlayout.py", line 481, in apply
    self.apply_callback(self.formwidget.get())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/matplotlib/backends/qt_editor/figureoptions.py", line 194, in apply_callback
    axes.set_xlabel(xlabel)
  File "/home/beischer/repos/astropy/astropy/visualization/wcsaxes/core.py", line 471, in set_xlabel
    raise TypeError("set_xlabel() missing 1 required positional argument: 'xlabel'")
TypeError: set_xlabel() missing 1 required positional argument: 'xlabel'
zsh: abort (core dumped)  MPLBACKEND=Qt5Agg python test_mpl.py
```

### Steps to Reproduce

Consider this script:
```python
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from astropy.visualization.wcsaxes.frame import EllipticalFrame
from astropy.io import fits
from astropy.wcs import WCS
from astropy import units as u

data = np.ones((360,720))

header = fits.Header()
header['BITPIX'] = -32
header['NAXIS']  = 2
header['NAXIS1'] = 720
header['CRPIX1'] = 360.5
header['CRVAL1'] = 0.0
header['CDELT1'] = -0.5
header['CTYPE1'] = 'RA---AIT'
header['CUNIT1'] = 'deg'
header['NAXIS2'] = 360
header['CRPIX2'] = 180.5
header['CRVAL2'] = 0.0
header['CDELT2'] = 0.5
header['CTYPE2'] = 'DEC--AIT'

w = WCS(header)
pix_l_min, _ = w.all_world2pix(179.9, 0.0, 0)
pix_l_max, _ = w.all_world2pix(-179.9, 0.0, 0)
_, pix_b_min = w.all_world2pix(0, -89.9, 0)
_, pix_b_max = w.all_world2pix(0,  89.9, 0)

plt.figure()
plt.subplot(projection = w, frame_class=EllipticalFrame)
im = plt.imshow(data, origin='lower', cmap='jet')
ax = plt.gca()
ax.coords.grid(color='black', ls='dotted')
lon = ax.coords[0]
lat = ax.coords[1]
lon.set_axislabel('Right Ascension', color='black')
lat.set_axislabel('Declination', color='black')
lon.set_major_formatter('d')
lat.set_major_formatter('d')
lon.set_ticklabel(color='black')
lat.set_ticklabel(color='black')
lon.set_ticks(spacing = 60 * u.degree, color='black')
lat.set_ticks(spacing = 30 * u.degree, color='black')
im.set_clip_path(ax.coords.frame.patch)
plt.xlim(pix_l_min, pix_l_max)
plt.ylim(pix_b_min, pix_b_max)
plt.show()
```

1. MPLBACKEND=Qt5Agg python test_mpl.py
2. Click on the 'edit axis' button (z-shaped arrow pointing to the top right)
3. Click on 'Images, etc.'
4. Change 'Min. value'
5. Click 'Apply'

items.title: Change order of operations in setup.py
items.body:
In the ``setup.py`` file we should make sure that the checks for the ``test`` and ``build_docs`` commands come *before* the extension-helpers imports, otherwise contributors who don't have extension-helpers installed will see an import error when trying to run ``python setup.py test`` rather than the help messages. This will also need to be fixed in the coordinated packages and the package template.

(cc @aarchiba since this affected you today!)

items.title: Possible bug in setting shape of Time, Representation, etc.
items.body:
Currently, setting the shape of a `Time` or `Representation` ~`SkyCoord`~ (edit: frames and sky coordinates cannot have their shape set) implies going through all attributes and trying to set their shape in turn, reverting if there is any `AttributeError` for items for which the shapes stride imply that the shape change is not possible. However, one can also get a `ValueError`, which should thus be checked as well. (Note that it is likely difficult to set up a state where this would actually cause a problem, so this does not have high priority)
```
In [5]: np.ones((3, 2)).T.shape = 6,                                            
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-384542aa1cc8> in <module>
----> 1 np.ones((3, 2)).T.shape = 6,

AttributeError: incompatible shape for a non-contiguous array

In [6]: np.ones((3, 2)).T.shape = 1, 2                                          
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-6-570b08d46880> in <module>
----> 1 np.ones((3, 2)).T.shape = 1, 2

ValueError: cannot reshape array of size 6 into shape (1,2)
```

items.title: Regression in astropy 4.0.1 with regard to Time objects in Tables
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

The problem is described in https://github.com/nanograv/PINT/issues/651

In particular, the comment https://github.com/nanograv/PINT/issues/651#issuecomment-633543751 contains a small script that can be used to reproduce the problem, which I'll paste below.

Basically it appears that Time instances can't be stored and extracted from a Table as they are. When running the script an error is reported. This problem seems to have been introduced in https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/9969. In particular, the problem disappears when commenting these lines:

```python
        # Hack from #9969 to allow passing the location value that has been
        # collected by the TimeAstropyTime format class up to the Time level.
        # TODO: find a nicer way.
        # print(self._time._location)
        if hasattr(self._time, '_location'):
            # from pudb import set_trace; set_trace(paused=True)
            self.location = self._time._location
            del self._time._location
```

This also appears to be related to lists of length 1. When using two elements in the initialization list there is no problem.

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
The script (below) should run without an error.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->

An exception is raised:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/core.py", line 543, in _get_time_fmt
    return cls(val, val2, scale, precision, in_subfmt, out_subfmt)
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/formats.py", line 147, in __init__
    val1, val2 = self._check_val_type(val1, val2)
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/formats.py", line 805, in _check_val_type
    raise TypeError('Input values for {} class must be '
TypeError: Input values for datetime class must be datetime objects

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 25, in <module>
    x = Time(grp['tdb'])
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/core.py", line 430, in __init__
    self._init_from_vals(val, val2, format, scale, copy,
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/core.py", line 485, in _init_from_vals
    self._time = self._get_time_fmt(val, val2, format, scale,
  File "/home/beischer/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/time/core.py", line 559, in _get_time_fmt
    raise ValueError(f'Input values did not match any of the formats '
ValueError: Input values did not match any of the formats where the format keyword is optional: {'datetime': TypeError('Input values for datetime class must be datetime objects'), 'ymdhms': ValueError('input must be dict or table-like'), 'iso': TypeError('Input values for iso class must be strings'), 'isot': TypeError('Input values for isot class must be strings'), 'yday': TypeError('Input values for yday class must be strings'), 'datetime64': TypeError('Input values for datetime64 class must be datetime64 objects'), 'fits': TypeError('Input values for fits class must be strings'), 'byear_str': TypeError('Input values for byear_str class must be strings'), 'jyear_str': TypeError('Input values for jyear_str class must be strings'), 'astropy_time': ValueError('cannot broadcast a non-scalar to a scalar array')}
```
### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python

from astropy.time import Time
from astropy.table import Table, Column
from astropy.coordinates import EarthLocation
import numpy as np

grp = Table()

time_mjd = Time([53801.38605118254], format='mjd', location=EarthLocation.from_geocentric(x=0., y=0., z=0., unit='m'))

# Broken
c1 = Column(name='mjd', data=time_mjd)
grp.add_columns([c1])
time_tdb = Time(grp['mjd'], location=grp['mjd'][0].location)

# # Works
# time_tdb = Time(time_mjd, location=time_mjd[0].location)

tdbs = np.asarray([t for t in time_tdb])

c2 = Column(name='tdb', data=tdbs)
grp.add_columns([c2])

x = Time(grp['tdb'])
```

items.title: Fitting of compound models too restrictive
items.body:
### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
@karllark reported on Slack:

I'm getting an interesting error when fitting a compound model.  The error is:
```
ValueError: Fitting a compound model without units can only be performed on
compound models that only use the arithmetic operators + and -
```
The model I'm fitting has units for a summed set of models including BlackBody, Drude1D, Gaussian1D models with units of MJy/sr that are then multiplied by a dust attenuation model that does not have units.

An example to reproduce the error:
```
import numpy as np
from astropy.modeling import fitting, models

fitter = fitting.LevMarLSQFitter()
model = models.BlackBody(temperature=3000 * u.K) * models.Const1D(amplitude=1.0)
    
x = [1.0, 2.0, 3.0] * u.micron
n = np.random.normal(3)
y = model(x) * (1.0 + n)
res = fitter(model, x, y)

```

_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

self = [<astropy.io.fits.hdu.image.PrimaryHDU object at 0x00000254411178C8>]

    def _flush_resize(self):
        """
        Implements flushing changes in update mode when parts of one or more HDU
        need to be resized.
        """

        old_name = self._file.name
        old_memmap = self._file.memmap
        name = _tmp_name(old_name)

        if not self._file.file_like:
            old_mode = os.stat(old_name).st_mode
            # The underlying file is an actual file object.  The HDUList is
            # resized, so we need to write it to a tmp file, delete the
            # original file, and rename the tmp file to the original file.
            if self._file.compression == 'gzip':
                new_file = gzip.GzipFile(name, mode='ab+')
            elif self._file.compression == 'bzip2':
                if not HAS_BZ2:
                    raise ModuleNotFoundError(
                        "This Python installation does not provide the bz2 module.")
                new_file = bz2.BZ2File(name, mode='w')
            else:
                new_file = name

            with self.fromfile(new_file, mode='append') as hdulist:

                for hdu in self:
                    hdu._writeto(hdulist._file, inplace=True, copy=True)
                if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
                    # Collect a list of open mmaps to the data; this well be
                    # used later.  See below.
                    mmaps = [(idx, _get_array_mmap(hdu.data), hdu.data)
                             for idx, hdu in enumerate(self) if hdu._has_data]

                hdulist._file.close()
                self._file.close()
            if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
                # Close all open mmaps to the data.  This is only necessary on
                # Windows, which will not allow a file to be renamed or deleted
                # until all handles to that file have been closed.
                for idx, mmap, arr in mmaps:
                    if mmap is not None:
                        mmap.close()

            os.remove(self._file.name)

            # reopen the renamed new file with "update" mode
            os.rename(name, old_name)
            os.chmod(old_name, old_mode)

            if isinstance(new_file, gzip.GzipFile):
                old_file = gzip.GzipFile(old_name, mode='rb+')
            else:
                old_file = old_name

            ffo = _File(old_file, mode='update', memmap=old_memmap)

            self._file = ffo

            for hdu in self:
                # Need to update the _file attribute and close any open mmaps
                # on each HDU
                if hdu._has_data and _get_array_mmap(hdu.data) is not None:
                    del hdu.data
                hdu._file = ffo

            if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
                # On Windows, all the original data mmaps were closed above.
                # However, it's possible that the user still has references to
                # the old data which would no longer work (possibly even cause
                # a segfault if they try to access it).  This replaces the
                # buffers used by the original arrays with the buffers of mmap
                # arrays created from the new file.  This seems to work, but
                # it's a flaming hack and carries no guarantees that it won't
                # lead to odd behavior in practice.  Better to just not keep
                # references to data from files that had to be resized upon
                # flushing (on Windows--again, this is no problem on Linux).
                for idx, mmap, arr in mmaps:
                    if mmap is not None:
>                       arr.data = self[idx].data.data
E                       DeprecationWarning: Assigning the 'data' attribute is an inherently unsafe operation and will be removed in the future.

projects\astropy\astropy\io\fits\hdu\hdulist.py:1357: DeprecationWarning
============================= 1 failed, 1 passed, 17 skipped, 14723 deselected in 11.05s ==============================
```

Somehow the warning capture (see test decorator) is not working. Same goes for ``test_io_manipulation``. Note that this only fails if I'm in a folder where ``setup.cfg`` has no effect. I'll open a separate issue, but we should make sure that ``pytest --pyargs astropy`` always works even when no ``setup.cfg`` is present.

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
The routines for Poisson confidence intervals are made for the Poisson distribution which is relevant when counting something (e.g. photons). Thus, it should work when an integer number
is passed in.

<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
Calculate statistics

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->

items.title: GCRS to Al El
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
I was writing some test cases for my ERFA based conversions and found a curious case when compared against AstroPy. I am using AstroPy's own ERFA codes for a lot of the transformation work. I am trying to take an Observer at a Lat, Lon, and Height to find the Az El Dist (no atmospheric effects) to an object in GCRS Cartesian coordinates. Each sub-function checks out with only very slight errors (single digit meters, 10^-16 radians), but the end to end shows a substantial (100ish Arc Seconds) error. I put test cased illustrating all of this in the test file at this [repo](https://github.com/AshHarvey/astro-trans).

I suspect the error is on my side, but tests 1-5 seems to indicate all my sub functions agree. I must be missing something in the end to end case... I am not an astrophysics guy, so I will defer to those more experienced here.

If someone has another way to check ITRS / ITRS to Az El Dist, I would be interested in cross comparing.

May relate to:
Feature Request: https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/10239
Issue: https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/4269

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
I would expect arc second to sub-arc second agreement.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->
747 mean arc second az error across 8 test points, 347 mean arc second error in el, and distance errors nearing 1 meter or less

### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->

1. Clone GitHub [repo](https://github.com/AshHarvey/astro-trans)
2. Run test.py with Numpy, SciPy, AstroPy, PoliAstro, datetime, numba, and pandas installed (conda versions)

items.title: Spectral Coord tries to convert target to ICRS (even when it can't)
items.body:
When a spectral coord is constructed with a target (i.e. from the celestial axes of a WCS) but not an observer, and that target coordinate is unable to be transformed to ICRS it errors.

I discovered this in the NDCube test suite, and am currently unable to reproduce on its own. Opening this so I don't forget and so that it blocks 4.1.

items.title: Issue with MJDREF and MJD-OBS in WCS
items.body:
The following example demonstrates some peculiar behavior with respect to dates in WCS headers:

```python
In [8]: from astropy.io import fits                                                                                                                                              
   ...:  
   ...:  
   ...: HEADER = fits.Header.fromstring("""  
   ...: WCSAXES =                    2 / Number of coordinate axes  
   ...: DATE-OBS= '2011-02-15T00:00:00.34' / ISO-8601 time of observation  
   ...: MJD-OBS =      55607.000003935 / [d] MJD at start of observation  
   ...: """, sep="\n") 
   ...:                                                                                                                                                                          

In [9]: WCS(HEADER).to_header()                                                                                                                                                  
Out[9]: 
WCSAXES =                    2 / Number of coordinate axes                      
CRPIX1  =                  0.0 / Pixel coordinate of reference point            
CRPIX2  =                  0.0 / Pixel coordinate of reference point            
CDELT1  =                  1.0 / Coordinate increment at reference point        
CDELT2  =                  1.0 / Coordinate increment at reference point        
CRVAL1  =                  0.0 / Coordinate value at reference point            
CRVAL2  =                  0.0 / Coordinate value at reference point            
LATPOLE =                 90.0 / [deg] Native latitude of celestial pole        
MJDREFI =                  0.0 / [d] MJD of fiducial time, integer part         
MJDREFF =                  0.0 / [d] MJD of fiducial time, fractional part      
DATE-OBS= '2011-02-15T00:00:00.34' / ISO-8601 time of observation               
MJD-OBS =      55607.000003935 / [d] MJD of observation                         
MJD-OBS =      55607.000003935 / [d] MJD at start of observation  
```

The resulting header has MJDREFI and MJDREFF set both to 0 **and** a duplicate ``MJD-OBS`` entry. Round tripping via ``WCS`` again results in a warning and yet another keyword ``DATEREF``:

```python
In [11]: WCS(WCS(HEADER).to_header()).to_header()                                                                                                                                
WARNING: FITSFixedWarning: 'datfix' made the change 'Set DATE-REF to '1858-11-17' from MJD-REF'. [astropy.wcs.wcs]
Out[11]: 
WCSAXES =                    2 / Number of coordinate axes                      
CRPIX1  =                  0.0 / Pixel coordinate of reference point            
CRPIX2  =                  0.0 / Pixel coordinate of reference point            
CDELT1  =                  1.0 / Coordinate increment at reference point        
CDELT2  =                  1.0 / Coordinate increment at reference point        
CRVAL1  =                  0.0 / Coordinate value at reference point            
CRVAL2  =                  0.0 / Coordinate value at reference point            
LATPOLE =                 90.0 / [deg] Native latitude of celestial pole        
DATEREF = '1858-11-17'         / ISO-8601 fiducial time                         
MJDREFI =                  0.0 / [d] MJD of fiducial time, integer part         
MJDREFF =                  0.0 / [d] MJD of fiducial time, fractional part      
DATE-OBS= '2011-02-15T00:00:00.34' / ISO-8601 time of observation               
MJD-OBS =      55607.000003935 / [d] MJD of observation                         
MJD-OBS =      55607.000003935 / [d] MJD at start of observation   
```

This doesn't seem desirable, especially setting the date to 1858 by default at the end.

items.title: Initialising Table with structured dtype produces inconsistent/confusing results
items.body:
### Description
A discussion in the Facebook group brought up that a new, empty table can be constructed from an existing table by passing its `dtype`:
```
>>> oldtable.dtype
dtype([('wavelength', '<f8'), ('flux', '<f4'), ('uncertainty', '<f4')])
>>> Table(dtype=oldtable.dtype)
<Table length=0>
wavelength   flux  uncertainty
 float64   float32   float32  
---------- ------- -----------
```
and it is equally possible to initialise it in the more pedestrian manner
```
>>> newtable = Table(names=oldtable.colnames, dtype=[dt for n, dt in oldtable.dtype.descr])
```
but directly using the old `dtype` if `names` are already specified throws these exceptions:
```
 >>> newtable = Table(names=oldtable.colnames, dtype=oldtable.dtype)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/derek/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/table/table.py", line 621, in __init__
    self._check_names_dtype(names, dtype, n_cols)
  File "/Users/derek/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/table/table.py", line 873, in _check_names_dtype
    raise ValueError(f'{inp_str} must be a list or None')
ValueError: dtype must be a list or None

>>> newtable = Table(names=oldtable.colnames, dtype=oldtable.dtype.descr)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/derek/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/table/table.py", line 1088, in _convert_data_to_col
    col = col_cls(name=name, data=data, dtype=dtype,
  File "/Users/derek/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/table/column.py", line 879, in __new__
    self = super().__new__(
  File "/Users/derek/lib/python3.8/site-packages/astropy/table/column.py", line 254, in __new__
    if np.dtype(dtype).char == 'S':
TypeError: data type 'wavelength' not understood
```
The same happens when the `Table` is initialised with a structured array.

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->
`Table` should either raise a more meaningful error, or (perhaps preferably) accept the structured `dtype`, possibly with a warning that `dtype.names` will be replaced with the specified `names`.

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->
See above. While the recommended method in the docs `newtable = oldtable[:0].copy()` works (and has the advantage of additionally copying any `unit` properties), the discrepant behaviour between specifying `dtype` alone, and together with `names` is potentially confusing, and the exceptions not very clear.

https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/eeb9b7ac0e18b262fae64cd2fa46d0e1cff1e4d5/astropy/table/table.py#L592-L594

"unpacks" the `dtype` automatically when no other `names` information is available, and the same might be done with `names` set (but discarding `dtype.names`, since `names` should certainly take priority).
 
On a slightly related note, it would be convenient to have a method to directly get all units for the table columns in a form that could be passed as `units=`. Of course one can return to the `newtable = oldtable[:0].copy()` method, but if modifying names or dtypes is desired, such an option would come in handy.

### System Details
Astropy version 4.2.dev112+g595484597.
Date: 2020-05-22T19:44:39
Platform: macOS-10.12.6-x86_64-i386-64bit
Executable: /sw/bin/python3.8
Full Python Version: 
3.8.3 (default, May 14 2020, 22:17:35) 
[Clang 9.0.0 (clang-900.0.39.2)]

Package versions:
Numpy: 1.19.0rc1
Scipy: 1.4.1
Matplotlib: 3.2.1
h5py: 2.9.0
Pandas: not available
Cython: 0.29.16

items.title: Test failure in io.votable when building wheels on MacPython
items.body:
I'm seeing the following test failure on Travis in the wheel building machinery, and am not quite sure why it hasn't happened in our CI. Does anyone have any ideas what could cause this?

```
_____________________________ test_unicode_as_char _____________________________

    def test_unicode_as_char():

        config = {'verify': 'exception'}

        field = tree.Field(

            None, name='unicode_in_char', datatype='char',

            arraysize='*', config=config)

        c = converters.get_converter(field, config=config)

    

        # Test parsing.

        c.parse('XYZ')  # ASCII succeeds

        with pytest.raises(

                exceptions.W55,

                match=r'FIELD \(unicode_in_char\) has datatype="char" but contains non-ASCII value'):

>           c.parse("zła")  # non-ASCII

../venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astropy/io/votable/tests/converter_test.py:81: Failed

=============================== warnings summary ===============================
```

I'll try and investigate some more, but putting this up here in case anyone is able to reproduce this and/or knows how to fix it :)

items.title: BinTableHdu Data is Available at Surprising Times
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
HDU data is available at surprising times.
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

### Expected behavior
I expected that either the HDU data is never available outside the context manager or that `hdus.readall()` would cause the same behavior as accessing `hdus[1].data`. See the attached example.
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->

### Actual behavior
<!-- What actually happened. -->
See attached script for an example.
<!-- Was the output confusing or poorly described? -->

### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Ideally a code example could be provided so we can run it ourselves. -->
<!-- If you are pasting code, use triple backticks (```) around
your code snippet. -->
<!-- If necessary, sanitize your screen output to be pasted so you do not
reveal secrets like tokens and passwords. -->
```python
import numpy as np
import os
from astropy.io import fits
from astropy.io.fits.hdu.hdulist import fitsopen

filepath = os.path.expanduser("~/Downloads/foo.fits")
c1 = fits.Column(name='a', array=np.array([1, 2]), format='K')
c2 = fits.Column(name='b', array=np.array([4, 5]), format='K')
c3 = fits.Column(name='c', array=np.array([7, 8]), format='K')
t = fits.BinTableHDU.from_columns([c1, c2, c3])
t.writeto(filepath)

print("Let's open that file and then try to access the data.")
with open(filepath, mode='rb') as fo:
    hdus = fitsopen(fo, mode='readonly', lazy_load_hdus=False)
    
try:
    hdus[1].data
except ValueError as e:
    print("That's an exception!")
    print("Ok, cool, so the data isn't available outside of the context manager. Makes enough sense."
          "Maybe setting lazy loading to False doesn't mean exactly what I thought.")

with open(filepath, mode='rb') as fo:
    hdus = fitsopen(fo, mode='readonly', lazy_load_hdus=False)
    hdus[1].data
print("This should raise an exception, right? I mean, I didn't actually _do_ anything")
hdus[1].data
print('Wait... what? Why did that work? Oh, I must have to read all the HDUs before they are available '
      'outside the context manager.')

print('Well, surely we can just read all the HDUS into memory and then they will be accessible outside'
      'of the context manager, right?')
with open(filepath, mode='rb') as fo:
    hdus = fitsopen(fo, mode='readonly', lazy_load_hdus=False)
    hdus.readall()

try:
    hdus[1].data
except ValueError as e:
    print("WUT?")
    raise
```

### System Details
<!-- Even if you do not think this is necessary, it is useful information for the maintainers.
Please run the following snippet and paste the output below:
import platform; print(platform.platform())
import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
import numpy; print("Numpy", numpy.__version__)
import astropy; print("astropy", astropy.__version__)
import scipy; print("Scipy", scipy.__version__)
-->
