Python 3.8.2 (default, Apr  3 2020, 16:45:01) 
[Clang 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4)]

astropy 4.0.1.post1

items.title: Sphinx directives visible in rendered docs
items.body:
Neither the example directive commands nor `doctest-requires` should be visible in the rendered docs

https://docs.astropy.org/en/latest/coordinates/satellites.html#astropy-coordinates-satellites

items.title: Refactor download mechanism to use requests?
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the feature you would like. -->
<!-- If you want to, you can suggest a draft design or API. -->
<!-- This way we have a deeper discussion on the feature. -->

There are a lot of code that can be removed if we switch from using `urllib` to `requests`. However, it is somewhat controversial because it adds `requests` as a required dependency.

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. -->
<!-- This part is optional. -->

`astroquery` has to roll its down download function because ours don't support things that `requests` support like streaming and range. Adding those functionalities ourselves are more work than it is worth.

cc @keflavich

items.title: Remove duplicated API references
items.body:
Both LS and BLS are still listed in the stats API references generated by automodapi while there have been moved to timeseries and deprecated from the stats namespace.

A well placed `__all__` would probably be enough to avoid this.

items.body:
Both PEP 8 checks in CircleCI (under html job) and Travis CI are failing with similar errors. Example from CircleCI:

codestyle installdeps: flake8

This is blocking PR testing (and hence, merges).

Hello all, I've been trying to crop a fits file and for the life of me it cannot go through even after reading and watching some videos that do this. I am using Windows 10 OS with Anaconda fully installed.

items.title: Add documentation for wtbarr structure

Document `Wtbarr` structure and its members. This was missed in #9641. I will work on this.

EDIT: #9641 was milestoned to 4.1

items.title: Expose wcsprm.aux in astropy.wcs
items.body:
WCSLIB 7.1 includes auxiliary parameters on an ``auxprm`` object:

```
  - Support Solar keywords RSUN_REF, DSUN_OBS, CRLN_OBS, CRLT_OBS,
    HGLN_OBS, and HGLT_OBS by accomodating them within an auxiliary
    struct, auxprm, within the wcsprm struct.  Now filled by the header
    parsers, wcspih() and wcsbth() and handled routinely by wcsinit(),
    wcssub(), wcscompare(), wcsfree(), wcsprt(), wcsset(), and wcshdo().
    Requested by Stuart Mumford (SunPy) with input from Bill Thompson.
```

We should expose these parameters in ``astropy.wcs``, either as an ``Wcsprm.aux`` or ``Wcsprm.auxprm`` property or a ``Wcsprm.get_aux`` method.

I gave this a try, but my C-foo isn't quite there yet, so I'd rather leave this to someone else more experienced with the inner workings of astropy.wcs! (cc @nden @mcara @MSeifert04)

items.title: `SkyCoord.separation_3d()` does not accept non-SkyCoord frames
items.body:
The documentation for `SkyCoord.separation_3d()` claims that it accepts either SkyCoords or frames.  However:
```python
>>> from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord, ICRS, FK5
>>> s = SkyCoord(0*u.deg, 0*u.deg, 0*u.AU, frame=ICRS)
>>> f = FK5(0*u.deg, 0*u.deg, 0*u.AU)

>>> s.separation_3d(f)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
c:\users\ayshih\onedrive\code\astropy\astropy\coordinates\sky_coordinate.py in separation_3d(self, other)
   1055             try:
-> 1056                 other = other.transform_to(self, merge_attributes=False)
   1057             except TypeError:

TypeError: transform_to() got an unexpected keyword argument 'merge_attributes'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-19-4e217804ac3a> in <module>
----> 1 s.separation_3d(FK5(0*u.deg, 0*u.deg, 0*u.AU))

c:\users\ayshih\onedrive\code\astropy\astropy\coordinates\sky_coordinate.py in separation_3d(self, other)
   1056                 other = other.transform_to(self, merge_attributes=False)
   1057             except TypeError:
-> 1058                 raise TypeError('Can only get separation to another SkyCoord '
   1059                                 'or a coordinate frame with data')
   1060

TypeError: Can only get separation to another SkyCoord or a coordinate frame with data

>>> s.separation_3d(SkyCoord(f))
<Distance 0. AU>
```
I thought this used to work fine, and but maybe not for years (since 2.0)?  `SkyCoord.separation()` has the same issue.

Someone should decide whether the implementation should be fixed to match the documentation or the other way around.

    def _parse_coordinate_data(frame, args, kwargs):
        """
        Extract coordinate data from the args and kwargs passed to SkyCoord.
    
        By this point, we assume that all of the frame attributes have been
        extracted from kwargs (see _get_frame_without_data()), so all that are left
        are (1) extra SkyCoord attributes, and (2) the coordinate data, specified in
        any of the valid ways.
        """
        valid_skycoord_kwargs = {}
        valid_components = {}
        info = None
    
        # Look through the remaining kwargs to see if any are valid attribute names
        # by asking the frame transform graph:
        attr_names = list(kwargs.keys())
        for attr in attr_names:
            if attr in frame_transform_graph.frame_attributes:
                valid_skycoord_kwargs[attr] = kwargs.pop(attr)
    
        # By this point in parsing the arguments, anything left in the args and
        # kwargs should be data. Either as individual components, or a list of
        # objects, or a representation, etc.
    
        # Get units of components
        units = _get_representation_component_units(args, kwargs)
    
        # Grab any frame-specific attr names like `ra` or `l` or `distance` from
        # kwargs and move them to valid_components.
        valid_components.update(_get_representation_attrs(frame, units, kwargs))
    
        # Error if anything is still left in kwargs
        if kwargs:
            # The next few lines add a more user-friendly error message to a
            # common and confusing situation when the user specifies, e.g.,
            # `pm_ra` when they really should be passing `pm_ra_cosdec`. The
            # extra error should only turn on when the positional representation
            # is spherical, and when the component 'pm_<lon>' is passed.
            pm_message = ''
            if frame.representation_type == SphericalRepresentation:
                frame_names = list(frame.get_representation_component_names().keys())
                lon_name = frame_names[0]
                lat_name = frame_names[1]
    
                if f'pm_{lon_name}' in list(kwargs.keys()):
                    pm_message = ('\n\n By default, most frame classes expect '
                                  'the longitudinal proper motion to include '
                                  'the cos(latitude) term, named '
                                  '`pm_{}_cos{}`. Did you mean to pass in '
                                  'this component?'
                                  .format(lon_name, lat_name))
    
            raise ValueError('Unrecognized keyword argument(s) {}{}'
                             .format(', '.join(f"'{key}'"
                                               for key in kwargs),
>                                    pm_message))

items.title: sunpy wcs animator tests failing with astropy 4.1
items.body:
This is the upstream version of https://github.com/sunpy/sunpy/issues/4096. 

The block here (introduced in https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/10185) is being triggered by sunpy tests:
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/441486c8cf1d80409520ea756cf006932cb57c77/astropy/wcs/wcsapi/fitswcs.py#L439-L447

where `frame='helioprojective'`, a built in `sunpy` frame. The helioprojective frame doesn't support a `radial_velocity` kwarg though:
```
SkyCoord(0, 0, frame='helioprojective', unit='rad', radial_velocity=0*u.km/u.s)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/dstansby/github/astropy/astropy/coordinates/sky_coordinate.py", line 313, in __init__
    skycoord_kwargs, components, info = _parse_coordinate_data(
  File "/Users/dstansby/github/astropy/astropy/coordinates/sky_coordinate_parsers.py", line 268, in _parse_coordinate_data
    raise ValueError('Unrecognized keyword argument(s) {}{}'
ValueError: Unrecognized keyword argument(s) 'radial_velocity'
```
causing the CI error. I'm struggling to make a self contained example to trigger the block at the moment.

items.title: pix2world which pixel reference system?
items.body:
Hi,

I'm try to use the function pix2world. 
what I can not understand is in which pixel reference system I should give the pixels coordinates to convert it

Since for standard the the origin pixel of an image is defined as the pixel (0, 0) in the upper left corner instead in fit format the origin pixel of is defined as pixel (1, 1) in the lower left corner.

in which system I need to pass to pix2world the coordinate of an object?

thanks

items.title: TST: Why so many conftest.py files?
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

I see many copies of `conftest.py` files buried in the package. The most troubling are `astropy/conftest.py` and `conftest.py` that contain duplicated code.

1. `astropy/coordinates/tests/conftest.py`
2. `astropy/table/tests/conftest.py`
3. `astropy/wcs/tests/conftest.py`
4. `astropy/wcs/wcsapi/conftest.py`
5. `astropy/conftest.py`
6. `docs/conftest.py`
7. `conftest.py`

### Expected behavior
<!-- What did you expect to happen. -->

One and only one `conftest.py` at root directory.

### Proposed solution

* Move stuff from lower level `conftest.py` files to the root level one. Eliminated duplicate code.
* Move subpackage specfici test helper functions into `subpackage/tests/utils.py` if they are not needed at the root `conftest.py` level.

### Need to know

* Is there a reason why proposed solution above wouldn't work?

items.title: TST: Consider using a local copy of sites.json for testing
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->

Several `coordinates` tests now chronically fail. They pull `sites.json` from data server and are marked as "remote data" but the server is now denying access. I don't know if they would work again once the CI traffic decreases or not; i.e., if the blacklist is temporary or permanent. Because of these failures, maintainers might miss real "remote data" failures that need to be fixed (e.g., #10297 and #10299).

What are these tests really testing? Do they really need to be on the whim of internet? Can we use a local copy of `sites.json` and not mark them as "remote data"?

Example log: https://travis-ci.org/github/astropy/astropy/jobs/683016071

```

items.title: Changes to SkyCoord equality incompatible with a SkyCoord frame attribute
items.body:
In sunpy one of the frame attributes we set on some of our frames is an `observer` attribute, which is itself a `SkyCoord`. The recent changes to coordinate equality checking in https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/10154 break some functionality however, because `sc1 != sc2` now errors instead of returning `False` if `sc1` is in a different frame to `sc2`.

In particular, a traceback where we are now seeing errors is
```
>       assert_quantity_allclose(implicit.separation_3d(explicit2), 0*u.AU, atol=1e-10*u.AU)

sunpy/coordinates/tests/test_transformations.py:500: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
../astropy/astropy/coordinates/sky_coordinate.py:1054: in separation_3d
    if not self.is_equivalent_frame(other):
../astropy/astropy/coordinates/sky_coordinate.py:970: in is_equivalent_frame
    if np.any(getattr(self, fattrnm) != getattr(other, fattrnm)):
../astropy/astropy/coordinates/baseframe.py:1656: in __ne__
    return np.logical_not(self == value)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

self = <HeliographicStonyhurst Coordinate (obstime=2019-06-01T00:00:00.000): (lon, lat, radius) in (deg, deg, AU)
    (0., -0.72605048, 1.01396311)>
value = <HeliographicStonyhurst Coordinate (obstime=2019-12-01T00:00:00.000): (lon, lat, radius) in (deg, deg, AU)
    (0., 0.94857499, 0.98618233)>

    def __eq__(self, value):
        """Equality operator for frame.
    
        This implements strict equality and requires that the frames are
        equivalent and that the representation data are exactly equal.
        """
        is_equiv = self.is_equivalent_frame(value)
    
        if self._data is None and value._data is None:
            # For Frame with no data, == compare is same as is_equivalent_frame()
            return is_equiv
    
        if not is_equiv:
>           raise TypeError(f'cannot compare: objects must have equivalent frames: '
                            f'{self.replicate_without_data()} vs. '
                            f'{value.replicate_without_data()}')
E           TypeError: cannot compare: objects must have equivalent frames: <HeliographicStonyhurst Frame (obstime=2019-06-01T00:00:00.000)> vs. <HeliographicStonyhurst Frame (obstime=2019-12-01T00:00:00.000)>
```

Because `is_equivalent_frame`  checks all the attrs in this line:
```
../astropy/astropy/coordinates/sky_coordinate.py:970: in is_equivalent_frame
    if np.any(getattr(self, fattrnm) != getattr(other, fattrnm)):
```
it will check our observer attribute, but now the `!=` call raises an error instead of just returning `False`, when `self` and `other` are not in the same frame.

I'm not entirely sure what the best way to solve this is. One the one hand, I see conceptually why an error is now raised when trying to compare coordinates in two different frames. On the other hand, I'm not sure how to practically solve this new issue, without making `!=` return `True` when the two frames are different.

items.title: API change docs for coordinate equality change in wrong place
items.body:
It looks like the API change note for the changes in  https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/10154 is in the wrong place: https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/10154/files#diff-db23dcd814354c954091a9b90dbfd92aR251 is under the heading `
astropy.io.ascii`, but it seems to me like it should be under `astropy.coordinates`.

items.title: Allow table.vstack with tables that have coordinate mixin columns
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the feature you would like. -->
<!-- If you want to, you can suggest a draft design or API. -->
<!-- This way we have a deeper discussion on the feature. -->
I was trying to stack two tables with observations information (XMM and Chandra data in my case). Each table already has a column with a coordinate mixin column, but I can't stack them:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NotImplementedError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-273-9fe785878676> in <module>
----> 1 all_data = table.vstack([chandra_data, xmm_data])

/nfs/melkor/d1/guenther/soft/anaconda/envs/ciao412/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/table/operations.py in vstack(tables, join_type, metadata_conflicts)
    290     col_name_map = OrderedDict()
    291 
--> 292     out = _vstack(tables, join_type, col_name_map, metadata_conflicts)
    293 
    294     # Merge table metadata

/nfs/melkor/d1/guenther/soft/anaconda/envs/ciao412/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/table/operations.py in _vstack(arrays, join_type, col_name_map, metadata_conflicts)
    854         if not hasattr(col_cls.info, 'new_like'):
    855             raise NotImplementedError('vstack unavailable for mixin column type(s): {}'
--> 856                                       .format(col_cls.__name__))
    857         try:
    858             out[out_name] = col_cls.info.new_like(cols, n_rows, metadata_conflicts, out_name)

NotImplementedError: vstack unavailable for mixin column type(s): SkyCoord

```

This is not a critical feature because I can work around it easily (just delete the mixin column, stack, recreate the mixin column from RA/DEC information that I have in other columns) but it would be nice to have. I see that stacking columns might not be easy (e.g. they could use different reference systems), but maybe stacking could work at least in the simplest (and probably most common) case where the frames are identical.

items.title: Seamless integration of WCS with coordinates
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

### Description
WCS objects should work with astropy coordinates, i.e. `all_world2pix` should accept a coordinate (vector) on input and `all_pix2world` should return a coordinate object.

Here is an example:
```
from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord
from astropy import wcs
import astropy.units as u

# For this example, I build a WCS from scratch so that the issue can be run easily
# but in reality I would load a WCS from a fits image
w = wcs.WCS(naxis=2)
w.wcs.crpix = [165.5,-34.7]
w.wcs.cdelt = [-0.066667, 0.066667]
w.wcs.crval = [0, -90]
w.wcs.ctype = ["RA---AIR", "DEC--AIR"]
w.wcs.set_pv([(2, 1, 45.0)])
```
I can do:
```
myobj = SkyCoord(*w.all_pix2world(123, 234, 0), unit=u.deg)
```
but would it not be much easier if the WCS already returned a coodiante?

The same is true the other way around:
```
twhya = SkyCoord.from_name('TW Hya')
w.all_world2pix(twhya.ra.deg, twhya.dec.deg, 0)
```
The following would be a lot more integrated, but fails:
```
w.all_world2pix(twhya, 0)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-184-7c8278221f9c> in <module>
----> 1 w.all_world2pix(twhya)

/nfs/melkor/d1/guenther/soft/anaconda/envs/ciao412/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/wcs/wcs.py in all_world2pix(self, tolerance, maxiter, adaptive, detect_divergence, quiet, *args, **kwargs)
   1859                 adaptive=adaptive, detect_divergence=detect_divergence,
   1860                 quiet=quiet),
-> 1861             'input', *args, **kwargs
   1862         )
   1863 

/nfs/melkor/d1/guenther/soft/anaconda/envs/ciao412/lib/python3.7/site-packages/astropy/wcs/wcs.py in _array_converter(self, func, sky, ra_dec_order, *args)
   1310             "dimension, and the origin argument). Instead, {2} arguments were "
   1311             "given.".format(
-> 1312                 self.naxis, self.naxis + 1, len(args)))
   1313 
   1314     def all_pix2world(self, *args, **kwargs):

TypeError: WCS projection has 2 dimensions, so expected 2 (an Nx2 array and the origin argument) or 3 arguments (the position in each dimension, and the origin argument). Instead, 1 arguments were given.

```
### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. -->
<!-- This part is optional. -->
We don't want to break backwards compatibility for a function as basic as this one, but we could do the following:

- for `all_world2pix` check if input is an instance of SkyCoord and treat that correctly
- for `all_world2pix`have a keyword like `return_coord_object = True`.

Note that this does not collide with APE14, which adds an WCS interface layer, but does not prohibit lower-level, existing WCS implementations to understand coordinates.

items.title: Issue with custom equivalency involving use of a constant
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

<!-- Please check that the development version still produces the same bug.
You can install development version with
pip install git+https://github.com/astropy/astropy
command. -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the bug. -->
I obtain an incorrect conversion when involving `astropy.constants` (h) in a custom equivalency

### Snippet to reproduce
```python
import astropy.units as u
import numpy as np
from astropy.constants import m_e, h

mec2 = m_e.to("erg", equivalencies=u.mass_energy())
epsilon_equivalencies = [
    (u.Hz, u.Unit(""), lambda x: h * x / mec2, lambda x: x * mec2 / h)
]
nu = np.logspace(23, 28, 10) * u.Hz
# dimensionless energy in electron rest mass energy units
epsilon = (h * nu / mec2).to("")
print("manual conversion: ", epsilon)

epsilon = nu.to("", equivalencies=epsilon_equivalencies)
print("equivalencies conversion: ", epsilon)
```
The output reads
```bash
manual conversion:  [8.09329979e+02 2.90858114e+03 1.04528986e+04 3.75657700e+04
 1.35004377e+05 4.85180576e+05 1.74364858e+06 6.26634810e+06
 2.25200874e+07 8.09329979e+07]
equivalencies conversion:  [8.09329979e-05 2.90858114e-04 1.04528986e-03 3.75657700e-03
 1.35004377e-02 4.85180576e-02 1.74364858e-01 6.26634810e-01
 2.25200874e+00 8.09329979e+00]
```
The difference is a factor `1e-7`, which is exactly the factor between `h` in SI and cgs units.
The issue can be avoided by explicitly converting h in cgs inside the equivalency
```python
epsilon_equivalencies = [
    (u.Hz, u.Unit(""), lambda x: h.cgs * x / mec2, lambda x: x * mec2 / h.cgs)
]
```
Why the equivalency cannot handle the simplification correctly?

### System Details
<!-- Even if you do not think this is necessary, it is useful information for the maintainers.
Please run the following snippet and paste the output below:
import platform; print(platform.platform())
import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
import numpy; print("Numpy", numpy.__version__)
import astropy; print("astropy", astropy.__version__)
import scipy; print("Scipy", scipy.__version__)
-->
Darwin-19.4.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.7.6 (default, Jan  8 2020, 13:42:34) 
[Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
Numpy 1.18.1
astropy 4.0.1.post1
Scipy 1.4.1

Have I misunderstood the use of custom equivalencies?
Thank you!

items.title: Adjust get_body to take into account location on Earth
items.body:
In https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/10230#issuecomment-622655253, @mkbrewer noted that our `solar_system._get_apparent_body_position`, which is used in `get_body`, corrects for travel time to the center of the Earth rather than the actual location of the observer. While in general the resulting differences of a ms is not going to affect any of the locations of the planets at a level one likely cares about, the actual travel time is iterated on until it is less than `10 ns`, which is suggesting better precision. And the [docstring for `get_body`](https://docs.astropy.org/en/latest/api/astropy.coordinates.get_body.html#astropy.coordinates.get_body) also seems to suggest the actual location of the observer is used. cc @StuartLittlefair 

Also, crossref https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/10230#issuecomment-622659492, in which @ayshih mentions a sunpy routine that calculates light-travel times for an arbitrary observer.

items.title: Add TEME tests that are not remote_data
items.body:
#10149 added the TEME frame, and included necessary unit tests.  However, the tests are `remote_data` because that makes sense for the obvious uses cases for this frame (satellites).  It's not a huge priority, but it would be a bit more robust (and make our coverage stats look better) if there were some tests for this frame that didn't require remote data.

cc @StuartLittlefair

items.title: Upstream release of dependency: cfitsio
items.body:
<!-- This comments are hidden when you submit the issue,
so you do not need to remove them! -->

<!-- Please be sure to check out our contributing guidelines,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md .
Please be sure to check out our code of conduct,
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md . -->

<!-- Please have a search on our GitHub repository to see if a similar
issue has already been posted.
If a similar issue is closed, have a quick look to see if you are satisfied
by the resolution.
If not please go ahead and open an issue! -->

### Description
<!-- Provide a general description of the feature you would like. -->
<!-- If you want to, you can suggest a draft design or API. -->
<!-- This way we have a deeper discussion on the feature. -->

This is a message from an automated system that monitors `cfitsio` releases.

Version 3.48 - Mar 2020

  - Now can handle parentheses in path names rather than automatically
    interpreting them as output file specifiers.  

  - Fixed bug in imcompress.c that wasn't properly handling conversion
    between float and double types when reading from a gzip compressed
    float or double image.
    
  - Fixed bug that was preventing use of bracket and parentheses symbols
    in pathnames when opening multiple READWRITE files, even when 
    requesting no-extended-syntax usage. *This fix necessitates a 
    library interface version number change.
    
  - Fixed bug in ffmnhd / fits_movnam_hdu to properly handle wildcard
    syntax.

  - Fixed bug in fits_open_extlist to handle filename[EXT] syntax
    properly.  The hdutype parameter may now be null.  More documentaion
    for this function is in cfitsio.tex.

  - Added new function fits_copy_hdutab to create a new table with the same
    structure as an existing table.

  - fits_copy_col / ffcpcl handles long long integer data types more
    natively to prevent precision loss.

  - histo.c routines now recognize integer columns that have been scaled by
    TSCALn keywords and may be closer to floating point type.
                   
  - Added backward compatibility for very old Rice compressed files which
    were not using the ZVAL2 keyword in the way that later became standard.

  - Change made to cfitsio.pc.in to prevent forcing downstream libraries
    to link against cfitsio's dependencies when using pkgconfig.

(For complete changelog information, consult the package changelog file in cfitsio/doc/changes.txt)

  **NOTE: This release introduces a SONAME change from 8 to 9.**

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. -->
<!-- This part is optional. -->

Reposting from spacetelescope/hstcal#476 . Thanks to @rendinam .

https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/FTP/software/fitsio/c/docs/changes.txt
